average_years_schooling.long_description: The Education Index measures the average education level achieved by the adult population in an area. This is based on the average years of schooling in an area. The calculation used to calculate the index can be found in (Bennett, D.L. Educational Inequailty in the United States: Methodology and Historical Estimates of Education Gini Coefficients. Econ. Modeling Microeconom. Stud. Health 2001). Higher educational attainment has been shown to have positive impacts on economic earning and positive health outcomes.

Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

Construction_entry_rate.long_description: Percent of new businesses (a new business is a company newly created or has moved to the region): \[entry\_rate=\frac{new\_businesses}{all\_businesses}\] in Construction. The Construction sector comprises establishments primarily engaged in the construction of buildings or engineering projects (e.g., highways and utility systems). earnings_per_job.long_description:
Earnings per job is calculated based on the GDP and Personal Income table from the Bureau of Economic Analysis(BEA).  Earnings per job is total earnings divided by total number of jobs. Total earnings is the sum of wages and salaries, supplements to wages and salaries, and proprietor’s income. Wages and salaries refer to the monetary remuneration of employees; it includes compensation of corporate officers; commissions, tips, and bonuses, compensation plans, such as 401(k) plans; and receipts in kind, or pay-in-kind, that represent income to the recipient. Supplements to wages and salaries consists of employer contributions for employee pension and insurance funds and employer contributions for government social insurance. Proprietor’s income is the current-production income (including the income in kind) of sole proprietorships and partnerships and of tax-exempt cooperatives.

Raw data observations are generally per county/city; however, some observations involve multiple counties/cities. For example, Fairfax County, Fairfax City and Falls Church City are grouped into one observation in the raw data.  We split the multi-county/city raw data observations into multiple observations so that one observation corresponds to only one county/city.  We set the value of each split individual observation to be that of the corresponding raw multi-county/city observation.

These are the multi-county/city groupings in the raw data: Albemarle County, Charlottesville; Alleghany County, Covington; Augusta County, Staunton, Waynesboro; Campbell County,  Lynchburg; Carroll County, Galax; Dinwiddie County, Colonial Heights, Petersburg; Fairfax County, Fairfax City, Falls Church; Frederick County, Winchester; Greensville County, Emporia; Henry County,  Martinsville; James City County, Williamsburg; Montgomery County, Radford; Pittsylvania County, Danville; Prince George County, Hopewell; Prince William County, Manassas, Manassas Park; Roanoke County, Salem; Rockbridge County, Buena Vista, Lexington; Rockingham County, Harrisonburg; Southampton County, Franklin; Spotsylvania County, Fredericksburg; Washington County, Bristol; Wise County, Norton; York County, Poquoson.

food_insecure_cnt.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the number of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
food_insecure_cnt.long_name: Estimated number of food insecure people
food_insecure_cnt.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

gini_index.long_description: The Gini Index is a summary measure of income inequality. The Gini coefficient incorporates the detailed shares data into a single statistic, which summarizes the dispersion of income across the entire income distribution. The Gini coefficient ranges from 0, indicating perfect equality (where everyone receives an equal share), to 1, perfect inequality (where only one recipient or group of recipients receives all the income). The Gini is based on the difference between the Lorenz curve (the observed cumulative income distribution) and the notion of a perfectly equal income distribution.
gini_index.short_description: The Gini Index is a summary measure of income inequality.

Information_entry_rate.long_description: Percent of new businesses (a new business is a company newly created or has moved to the region): \[entry\_rate=\frac{new\_businesses}{all\_businesses}\] in Information. Management of Companies and Enterprises_.long_description: Percent of new businesses (a new business is a company newly created or has moved to the region): \[entry\_rate=\frac{new\_businesses}{all\_businesses}\] in Management of Companies and Enterprises. The Management of Companies and Enterprises sector comprises (1) establishments that hold the securities of (or other equity interests in) companies and enterprises for the purpose of owning a controlling interest or influencing management decisions or (2) establishments (except government establishments) that administer, oversee, and manage establishments of the company or enterprise and that normally undertake the strategic or organizational planning and decision-making role of the company or enterprise. Establishments that administer, oversee, and manage may hold the securities of the company or enterprise.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=55&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 55}.

Manufacturing_entry_rate.long_description: Percent of new businesses (a new business is a company newly created or has moved to the region): \[entry\_rate=\frac{new\_businesses}{all\_businesses}\] in Manufacturing. The Manufacturing sector comprises establishments engaged in the mechanical, physical, or chemical transformation of materials, substances, or components into new products. The assembling of component parts of manufactured products is considered manufacturing, except in cases where the activity is appropriately classified in Sector 23, Construction.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=31&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 31-33}.

mental_3sfca.long_description: Mental health services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
mental_3sfca.long_name: Mental health services geographic availability (3-step  floating catchment areas)
mental_3sfca.short_description: Index of mental health services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

mental_3sfca.statement: The mental health services availability for {features.name} is {value}.

Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extra.long_description: Percent of new businesses (a new business is a company newly created or has moved to the region): \[entry\_rate=\frac{new\_businesses}{all\_businesses}\] in Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extraction. The Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extraction sector comprises establishments that extract naturally occurring mineral solids, such as coal and ores; liquid minerals, such as crude petroleum; and gases, such as natural gas. The term mining is used in the broad sense to include quarrying, well operations, beneficiating (e.g., crushing, screening, washing, and flotation), and other preparation customarily performed at the mine site, or as a part of mining activity.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=21&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 21}.

Num_Child_Food_Insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.statement: The population of food insecure children in {features.name} is {value}.

number_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the number of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
number_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated number of total people in food insecure households
number_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

obgyn_e2sfca.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online physician directory.

obgyn_e2sfca.short_description: Index of OBGYN care availability based on supply and demand of providers

_density.long_description: Population density, or number of people per square mile, as calculated from census ACS population data and shapefile areas: \[\frac{population_{r}}{meters^{2}_{r}}1609.344^{2}\] Where r is each region (e.g., census tract or county).

schools_{variant.name}_min_drivetime.short_description: Drive time to the nearest {variant} schools.
schools_{variant.name}_min_drivetime.long_description: Minimal drive time to a schools authorized to award {variant} from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
schools_{variant.name}_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest {variant} school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

2year.long_description: Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates

under2year.long_description: certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years

schools_2year_{category.name}.short_description: Number of 2-year schools{category} per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_{category.name}.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates{category} per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) qualifying 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_{category.name}.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools{category} per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

snap_shortfall_weighted_mean.long_description: The food shortfall money is the estimated amount of dollars that a household lacks to pay for the food costs. SNAP benefit is the dollar amount of dollars that a household may receive for supplemental food assistance after eligibility.  The SNAP shortfall is the ratio between the SNAP benefit divided by the food shortfall money.  The weighted average uses the number of households in different income categories, household combination and geography, and average is estimated for every census tract.
snap_shortfall_weighted_mean.short_description: The food shortfall money is the estimated amount of dollars that a household lacks to pay for the food costs

sources.name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Department   of Labor Women’s Bureau National
National   Bureau of Economic Research’s program TAXSIM Version 35

snap_weighted_mean.long_description: Weighted average of the dollar amount of Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefit.  The financial benefit is estimated following the guidelines and procedures from the Virginia Department of Social Services. The weighting component corresponds to the number of households in different income categories, household combination and geography.  The weighted average is obtained for every census tract.
snap_weighted_mean.short_description: Weighted average of the dollar amount of SNAP benefits

sources.name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development

National   Bureau of Economic Research’s program TAXSIM Version 35

Transportation and Warehousing_entry_rat.long_description: Percent of new businesses (a new business is a company newly created or has moved to the region): \[entry\_rate=\frac{new\_businesses}{all\_businesses}\] in Transportation and Warehousing. The Transportation and Warehousing sector includes industries providing transportation of passengers and cargo, warehousing and storage for goods, scenic and sightseeing transportation, and support activities related to modes of transportation. Establishments in these industries use transportation equipment or transportation related facilities as a productive asset. The type of equipment depends on the mode of transportation. The modes of transportation are air, rail, water, road, and pipeline.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=48&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 48-49}.

Utilities_entry_rate.long_description: Percent of new businesses (a new business is a company newly created or has moved to the region): \[entry\_rate=\frac{new\_businesses}{all\_businesses}\] in Utilities. The Utilities sector comprises establishments engaged in the provision of the following utility services: electric power, natural gas, steam supply, water supply, and sewage removal. Within this sector, the specific activities associated with the utility services provided vary by utility: electric power includes generation, transmission, and distribution; natural gas includes distribution; steam supply includes provision and/or distribution; water supply includes treatment and distribution; and sewage removal includes collection, treatment, and disposal of waste through sewer systems and sewage treatment facilities.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=22&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 22}.
